introduction.p: Every circuit has some capacitance due to the conductors of the circuit. A circuit with with significant capacitance is called a capacitative circuit.

sidebyside.p: In this section we will study current in a simple capacitative circuit with capacitance C and resistance R in series with an AC source with EMF, V(t) = V_0\cos(\omega t).

introduction.p:
By applying Faraday's law to the loop of the circuit, we show in a Calculus section below that current in the circuit is
I(t) = I_0 \cos(\omega t + \phi_I),
with
I_0 = \frac{V_0}{\sqrt{R^2 + ( 1/\omega C )^2 }},\ \ \ \ \phi_I = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{\omega R C}\right),
where 1/\omega C is the reactance of the capacitor.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Series RC Circuit

sidebyside.p:
Consider a circuit containing a resistor (R) and a capacitor (C) driven by a sinusoidal EMF as shown in the figure. Using voltage drops across each element, we get the following Faraday loop equation.
V_0\: \cos(\omega t) -\dfrac{1}{C}\int^t I(t') dt' - R I = 0.

subsection.p:
We will write this equation as
\frac{dI}{dt} + \dfrac{1}{RC} I = -\dfrac{\omega V_0}{R}\, \sin(\omega t),
and seek the steady state solution in the form
I(t) = I_0\,\cos(\omega t + \phi_I).
Using this in Eq. , expanding the trig functions, collecting coefficients of \sin(\omega t ) and \cos(\omega t), and solving for I_0 and \phi_I give the desired result in a similar calculations as done in .
I_0 = \frac{V_0}{\sqrt{R^2 + ( 1/\omega C )^2 }} \phi_I = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{\omega R C}\right)

remark.title: Impedance of an RC Circuit
remark.p:
The ratio of the amplitude of the voltage of the source to that of the current through the source has units of resistance. However, this quantity here consists of the contributions from capacitance and frequency. This quantity acts like overall resistance in the circuit. Just as in the RL circuit, we call this ratio amplitude of the impedance of the circuit and denote it by |Z|.
|Z| = \frac{\text{Amplitude of Voltage}}{\text{Amplitude of Current}} = \sqrt{R^2 + \left(1/\omega C\right)^2}.
The negative of the phase of overall current I(t) relative to the phase of the source emf gives the phase of impedance. Denoting this phase by \phi_Z, we have
\phi_Z = -\tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{1}{\omega R C}\right).

remark.title: RC Circuit at High and Low Frequencies

li.p: As the frequency of the driving EMF is increased, the capacitative reactance becomes smaller. Therefore an RC-circuit becomes more and more like a purely resistive circuit as capacitance becomes less important. Basically, at high frequency the capacitor never gets a chance to charge to any significant extent. The current in the circuit will be in-phase with the EMF, i.e., \phi\ \rightarrow\ 0, and the amplitude I_0 is obtained by ignoring the presence of capacitor, i.e., I_0\approx V_0/R.

At low frequencies of the driving EMF, the capacitative reactance becomes large and the resistor becomes less and less important in an RC-circuit. The phase constant of the current reaches +\pi/2 and the amplitude I_0 is simply given by ignoring the resistance R in the circuit, I_0 \approx \omega C V_0.

statement.p:
A 200\text{-}\mu\text{F} capacitor is connected across the terminals of a 15\text{-V} AC source (i.e. V_\text{rms} = \frac{V_0}{\sqrt{2}} = 15\text{ V}) of frequency 66\text{ Hz}. Assume zero resistance in the circuit. Find
the reactance of the capacitor,
the amplitude of impedance of the circuit,
the current amplitude,
the phase constant for current.

solution.p:
Using formulas for the corresponding quantities we get
X_C = \dfrac{1}{2\pi f C} = \dfrac{1}{2\pi \times 66\:\text{Hz}\times 200\:\mu\text{F}} = 12.1\: \Omega.
Since R=0 we will get
|Z| = \sqrt{R^2 + X_C^2} = 12.1\: \Omega.
I_0 = \dfrac{V_0}{|Z|} = \dfrac{\sqrt{2}\times 15\:\text{V}}{12.1\: \Omega} = 1.75\:\text{A}.
Since R=0 we will get
\phi_I = \tan^{-1}\left(\dfrac{X_C}{R} \right) = 90^{\circ}.

exercise.title: Current in a Capacitative Circuit with Varying Frequency
Capacitance of a Starter of a Fluorescent Light Bulb from Current and Voltage

statement.p: A starter for a fluorescent light bulb is a capacitor. When an AC voltage 170\; \text{V}\; \cos(2\pi\times 60 \times t) is applied across the capacitor, a peak current of 1.2 A flows in the capacitor. What is the capacitance?

exercise.title: RC Circuit as a Low Pass Filter

statement.p: A low-pass filter is a circuit that lets out low-frequency electrical signals while suppressing high-frequency signals. The frequency above which signal drops significantly is called the cutoff frequency of the low-pass filter.

sidebyside.p: A series RC-circuit with an AC signal source, shown in , can serve as a low pass filter if the output voltage is taken across the capacitor, the input voltage being the voltage of the source.

statement.p: Consider a circuit containing a 200\text{-}\Omega resistor and a 50\text{-}\mu\text{F} capacitor in series with a 18\text{-V} AC source of variable angular frequency \omega. (a) Determine the RMS-voltage across the capacitor (V_C) as a function of frequency, and (b) plot V_C/V_0 versus \omega for R = 1000\:\Omega and C = 10^{-6}\:\text{F} and find the cutoff frequency.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) We need the reactance X_C and the impedance Z of the circuit to find the phase and amplitude of the current.
X_C = \dfrac{1}{\omega C},\ \ Z = \sqrt{R^2 + X_C^2} = \sqrt{R^2 + \frac{1}{\omega^2C^2}}.
Therefore, the amplitude and phase of the current in the circuit are
I_0 = \dfrac{V_0}{Z} = \dfrac{V_0\:\omega C}{\sqrt{1 + \omega^2R^2C^2}},\ \ \tan \phi = \dfrac{1}{\omega RC}
The oscillating current is I(t) = I_0\:\cos(\omega t + \phi). Since the voltage across the capacitor lags the current by \pi/2 we get the following expression for the voltage V_C across the capacitor will be
V_C = I_0\:X_C\:\cos\left(\omega t + \phi - \frac{\pi}{2}\right).
This gives the following for the RMS-voltage across the capacitor.
V_{\text{C,rms}} \amp = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\:I_0\:X_C \amp = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\: \dfrac{V_0\:\omega C}{\sqrt{1 + \omega^2R^2C^2}}\: \dfrac{1}{\omega C} \amp = \dfrac{V_0}{\sqrt{2}}\: \dfrac{1 }{\sqrt{1 + \omega^2R^2C^2}}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: (b) In we plot V/V_0 versus \omega for R = 1000\:\Omega and C = 10^{-6}\:\text{F}. The time constant for this circuit will be \tau = RC = 10^{-3}\:\text{s}. It is seen that the output of the circuit drops to half the amplitude if the frequency goes beyond the cutoff frequency f_{\text{cutoff}} = \omega_{}/2\pi \approx 276\:\text{Hz}.

exercise.title: RC Circuit as a High Pass Filter

statement.p: A high-pass filter is a circuit that lets out high-frequency electrical signals while suppressing low-frequency signals. The frequency above which signal becomes significant is called the cutoff frequency of the high-pass filter.

sidebyside.p: A series RC-circuit with an AC signal source, shown in , can serve as a high-pass filter if the output voltage is taken across the resistor, the input voltage being the voltage of the source.

statement.p: Consider a circuit containing a 200\text{-}\Omega resistor and a 50\text{-}\mu\text{F} capacitor in series with a 18\text{-V} AC source of variable angular frequency \omega. (a) Determine the RMS-voltage across the capacitor (V_C) as a function of frequency, and (b) plot V_C/V_0 versus \omega for R = 1000\:\Omega and C = 10^{-6}\:\text{F} and find the cutoff frequency.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p:
(a) We need the reactance X_C and the impedance Z of the circuit to find the phase and amplitude of the current.
X_C = \dfrac{1}{\omega C},\ \ Z = \sqrt{R^2 + X_C^2} = \sqrt{R^2 + \frac{1}{\omega^2C^2}}.
Therefore, the amplitude and phase of the current in the circuit are
I_0 = \dfrac{V_0}{Z} = \dfrac{V_0\:\omega C}{\sqrt{1 + \omega^2R^2C^2}},\ \ \tan \phi = \dfrac{1}{\omega RC}
The oscillating current is I(t) = I_0\:\cos(\omega t + \phi). Since the voltage across the resistor is in phase with the current we get the following expression for the voltage V_R across the resistor will be
V_R = I_0\:R\:\cos\left(\omega t + \phi \right).
This gives the following for the RMS-voltage across the capacitor.
V_{\text{R,rms}} \amp = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\:I_0\:R \amp = \dfrac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\: \dfrac{V_0\:\omega R C}{\sqrt{1 + \omega^2R^2C^2}} \amp = \dfrac{V_0}{\sqrt{2}}\: \dfrac{\omega R C }{\sqrt{1 + \omega^2R^2C^2}}.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: (b) In we plot V_R(\text{rms})/V_0(\text{rms}) versus \omega in a log-log plot for R = 1000\:\Omega and C = 10^{-6}\:\text{F}. It is seen that the output of the circuit drops to half the amplitude if the frequency goes below the cutoff frequency f_{\text{cutoff}} = \omega_{\text{cutoff}}/2\pi \approx 92\:\text{Hz}.
